questions.question: Define: List in Python
questions.answer: A list is a collection of data that can be ordered, unordered, changeable and allows duplicate members. It is defined using square brackets [] and items are separated using commas.

questions.question: Define: Indentation
questions.answer: Indentation is the whitespace (spaces or tabs) at the beginning of a line of code. In Python, indentation is used to define blocks of code and tells the interpreter which statements belong together.

questions.question: Define: Iteration
questions.answer: Iteration means to go through element by element. In Python, the for loop is used to iterate through sequences such as strings and lists.

questions.question: Define: Condition
questions.answer: A condition in Python compares two pieces of information using relational operators and always returns a Boolean result (True or False). Conditions are used inside if-else statements to make decisions.

questions.question: Define: Boolean
questions.answer: Boolean is a data type that can have only two values: True or False. It is the result of comparisons and conditions in Python.

questions.question: Define: Relational Operators
questions.answer: Relational operators are symbols used to compare two values. The six relational operators in Python are: > (greater than), >= (greater than or equal to), < (lesser than), <= (lesser than or equal to), == (equal to), and != (not equal to).

questions.question: Define: for loop
questions.answer: A for loop is a control structure used to iterate through a sequence (like a list, string, or range). It executes a block of code for each item in the sequence.

questions.question: Define: range() function
questions.answer: The range() function is used to generate a sequence of numbers. It has three parameters: start (inclusive), stop (exclusive), and step. It is commonly used with for loops to repeat code a fixed number of times.

questions.question: Define: if-else statement
questions.answer: An if-else statement is a conditional statement used to make decisions in Python. If the condition is True, the if block executes; otherwise, the else block executes.

questions.question: Define: Modulus operator (%)
questions.answer: The modulus operator (%) returns the remainder of a division. For example, 10 % 3 gives 1. It is commonly used to check if a number is even (n % 2 == 0) or odd.

questions.question: Define: Index in a list
questions.answer: An index is the position number of an element in a list. Positive index starts from 0 for the first element. Negative index starts from -1 for the last element.

questions.question: Define: len() function
questions.answer: The len() function returns the number of items (length) in an object such as a list or string. For example, len([1, 2, 3]) returns 3.

questions.question: Define: input() function
questions.answer: The input() function is used to accept data from the user through the keyboard. It always returns the input as a string, so int() or float() may be needed to convert it to a number.

questions.question: Define: print() function
questions.answer: The print() function is used to display output on the screen. It can print strings, numbers, variables, and expressions.

questions.question: Define: time.sleep() function
questions.answer: The time.sleep() function pauses the execution of a program for a specified number of seconds. To use it, the time module must be imported first using 'import time'.

questions.question: Define: Positive Index
questions.answer: Positive index numbers start from 0 for the first item in the list. The first item has position 0, second item has position 1, and so on.

questions.question: Define: Negative Index
questions.answer: Negative index numbers start with -1 for the last element. They allow us to access the list from the end. -1 refers to the last item, -2 refers to the second last item, and so on.

questions.question: Define: Assignment Operator (=)
questions.answer: The assignment operator (=) is used to store a value in a variable. For example, a = 10 assigns the value 10 to the variable a.

questions.question: Define: Comparison Operator (==)
questions.answer: The comparison operator (==) is used to check if two values are equal. It returns True if they are equal and False if they are not. For example, 5 == 5 returns True.

questions.question: Define: Floor Division (//)
questions.answer: Floor division (//) divides two numbers and returns the integer part of the result, discarding the decimal. For example, 15 // 4 returns 3.
